Hello, everyone.

In the midst of my current writing project I am describin=
g replacing difficult-to-understand parameters with easier-to-understand on=
es. My particular example is boolean flags: in a positional-parameter langu=
age like Java, C or Ruby, it's virtually impossible to know just by looking=
 at a method call what "true" or "false" mean, especially in a method that =
has several such flags in the same parameter list.

What I'd love is a real=
-life example of this, preferably from a well-known library. If anyone has,=
 by chance, come across one of these monsters, I'd appreciate a reference.
=

In other words, a method like doIt(myObject, anotherObject, true, false, t=
rue, true);

What the hell does true, false, true, true mean?!

BTW: I'd ap=
preciate a CC: to me directly by e-mail, especially from the XP mailing lis=
t, since I can't keep up with the traffic on that list.

Thanks a bunch eve=
ryone!


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's writ=
e software that people understand.
http://www.diasparsoftware.com/

e: +1 416 791-8603
